awd_titl_txt: Effects of Turbulence on Droplet Evaporation and Combustion: Droplet-Resolved Direct Numerical Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
In most combustion engines used in automobiles and airplanes, fuel is injected in the form of the liquid. The evaporation of liquid fuel droplets and subsequent mixing with the surrounding air determine how fuel is ignited and burned. Turbulent fluid motions in the combustion engines enhance the rates of evaporation, mixing and burning. Better understanding of these processes will lead to more efficient engines. In this project, the effects of turbulence on the evaporation and combustion of fuel droplets will be investigated using a new computational method. Numerical simulations that resolve all relevant processes around and inside the droplets will be performed to advance the fundamental understanding of the droplet-turbulence-chemistry interactions under engine-relevant conditions. The advanced fundamental understanding will guide the improvement of engineering models and accelerate the development of combustion engines that meet future standards for fuel efficiency and pollutant emissions. The educational component includes the training of undergraduate and graduate students in computational combustion research and the K-12 outreach through an established program in the college.

The project is to characterize the effects of turbulence on droplet evaporation rates, inter-droplet scalar mixing, ignition, and flame structures, when the size of droplets is comparable to or larger than the Kolmogorov scale, the smallest turbulence length scale. A new computational method, which can enable the accurate and stable computation of droplet evaporation and combustion in turbulent flows under engine-relevant conditions, will be developed. Direct numerical simulation (DNS) of the evaporation and combustion of single-component and bi-component fuel droplets in homogeneous isotropic turbulence and in temporally developing mixing layers will be performed using the developed method. The DNS data will be analyzed to delineate the conditions under which the existing laminar theory for the droplet evaporation rates can be used. The emphasis of the analysis will also be placed on identifying the key parameters that characterize the turbulence effects on the evaporation rates. The small-scale mixing statistics in the vicinity of evaporating and burning droplets will be analyzed to help improve spray combustion modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In most combustion engines used in automobiles and airplanes, fuel is injected in the form of liquid. The liquid fuel evaporates, mixes with the surrounding air, and forms a combustible gas mixture. In practical combustion devices, all such processes are enhanced by fluid turbulence, seemingly random and chaotic motions of fluids. In this project, details of the physical processes that occur in the vicinity of fuel droplets are investigated through computational simulation, the knowledge of which helps develop or improve an advanced combustion strategy. A new numerical method is developed for this purpose. As the evaporation occurs on the surface of a fuel droplet, the droplet size is much smaller than the size of the combustion engine, and the processes of interest are highly non-linear, the device-scale computational simulation of all the processes without an engineering approximation requires a huge computational resource and remains a challenge. The emphasis of this project is placed on accurately simulating the effects of fluid turbulence on evaporation and scalar mixing processes, while the droplet shape and the processes inside the liquid droplet are simplified. The detailed numerical simulations performed in this project revealed interesting characteristics that are not observed during the combustion process of gases fuel and that have not been captured by existing engineering models. The project has advanced a fundamental understanding of the droplet-turbulence and droplet-droplet interactions under engine-relevant conditions. The advance in fundamental understanding and the data from detailed numerical simulations are expected to guide the improvement of engineering models and help the development of combustion engines that meet future standards for fuel efficiency and pollutant emissions. The developed numerical method is also applicable to other areas in chemical engineering and energy production, where particles are embedded in flows of gas or liquid. The educational component included the training of undergraduate and graduate students in computational combustion research. The undergraduate summer interns had an opportunity to work on the application of machine learning to a combustion-related problem and participated in the K-12 outreach through an established program in the PI's institution, called TEK-8 (Translating Engineering Research K-8).

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Seung Hyun Kim

Images (1 of )
  • Iso-octane fuel droplets (gray spheres) evaporate and interact in the presence of turbulence. The color plots on the sides represent the speed of turbulent flow motions of the ambient gas (red: high, blue: 0). The light blue color around the droplets represents the evaporated gaseous fuel.
    PI
    Copyrighted
    Seung Hyun Kim
    Computational simulation of a cluster of fuel droplets evaporating in turbulent flow
  • Iso-octane fuel droplets (gray spheres) evaporating in turbulent flow. The color plots on the sides represent the speed of turbulent flow motions of the ambient gas (red: high, blue: 0). The light blue color around the droplets represents the volume-rendered view of the evaporated gaseous fuel.
    PI
    Copyrighted
    Seung Hyun Kim
    Computational simulation of fuel droplets evaporating in turbulent flow
